abstract: A quantity sample type that measures the percentage of steps in which one foot moves at a different speed than the other when walking on flat ground.
overview:
## Discussion

Walking asymmetry is the percent of time that a user’s steps with one foot are faster or slower than the other foot. The system automatically records walking asymmetry samples on iPhone 8 or later. The user must carry their phone near their waist—such as in a pocket—and walk steadily on flat ground. The system records the phone’s location using the [doc://com.apple.healthkit/documentation/HealthKit/HKMetadataKeyDevicePlacementSide] metadata key. The system records 10 to 30 walking asymmetry samples on a typical day. iPhone doesn’t record walking asymmetry samples if the user’s wheelchair status is on.

These samples use percentage units (described in [doc://com.apple.healthkit/documentation/HealthKit/HKUnit]) and measure discrete values (described in [doc://com.apple.healthkit/documentation/HealthKit/HKQuantityAggregationStyle]). For example, the following code creates a percentage unit.

The sample’s [doc://com.apple.healthkit/documentation/HealthKit/HKQuantitySample/quantity] property represents the percent of asymmetrical steps between the sample’s [doc://com.apple.healthkit/documentation/HealthKit/HKSample/startDate] and [doc://com.apple.healthkit/documentation/HealthKit/HKSample/endDate] properties.

# walkingAsymmetryPercentage

**Type Property**

A quantity sample type that measures the percentage of steps in which one foot moves at a different speed than the other when walking on flat ground.

## Declaration

```swift
static let walkingAsymmetryPercentage: HKQuantityTypeIdentifier
```

## Discussion

Walking asymmetry is the percent of time that a user’s steps with one foot are faster or slower than the other foot. The system automatically records walking asymmetry samples on iPhone 8 or later. The user must carry their phone near their waist—such as in a pocket—and walk steadily on flat ground. The system records the phone’s location using the [doc://com.apple.healthkit/documentation/HealthKit/HKMetadataKeyDevicePlacementSide] metadata key. The system records 10 to 30 walking asymmetry samples on a typical day. iPhone doesn’t record walking asymmetry samples if the user’s wheelchair status is on.

These samples use percentage units (described in [doc://com.apple.healthkit/documentation/HealthKit/HKUnit]) and measure discrete values (described in [doc://com.apple.healthkit/documentation/HealthKit/HKQuantityAggregationStyle]). For example, the following code creates a percentage unit.

```swift
let percentage = HKUnit.percent()
```

The sample’s [doc://com.apple.healthkit/documentation/HealthKit/HKQuantitySample/quantity] property represents the percent of asymmetrical steps between the sample’s [doc://com.apple.healthkit/documentation/HealthKit/HKSample/startDate] and [doc://com.apple.healthkit/documentation/HealthKit/HKSample/endDate] properties.

## Related Documentation

- **HKDevicePlacementSide**: Values that indicate the placement of the device that measured a sample.

## Mobility

- **appleWalkingSteadiness**: A quantity sample type that measures the steadiness of the user’s gait.
- **appleWalkingSteadinessEvent**: A category sample type that records an incident where the user showed a reduced score for their gait’s steadiness.
- **sixMinuteWalkTestDistance**: A quantity sample type that stores the distance a user can walk during a six-minute walk test.
- **walkingSpeed**: A quantity sample type that measures the user’s average speed when walking steadily over flat ground.
- **walkingStepLength**: A quantity sample type that measures the average length of the user’s step when walking steadily over flat ground.
- **walkingDoubleSupportPercentage**: A quantity sample type that measures the percentage of time when both of the user’s feet touch the ground while walking steadily over flat ground.
- **stairAscentSpeed**: A quantity sample type measuring the user’s speed while climbing a flight of stairs.
- **stairDescentSpeed**: A quantity sample type measuring the user’s speed while descending a flight of stairs.
